Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Human-Robotic Interactions During Harvey Recovery Operations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Effective and efficient disaster recovery is necessary for individuals, the community and businesses to return to normal functioning from large-scale disasters, like hurricanes Harvey and Irma. In recent years, unmanned robots have been used to facilitate rescue, response, and recovery and have been found invaluable in these efforts as they can go where humans cannot. Although these robots do not have someone on the vehicle itself, they do require humans to operate them, and little is known about the demands of this technological work environment on the humans during disaster recovery. What is known is that the pilots often work: in high work demand stressful environments; outside (often in the heat, as hurricanes happen in the summer); require ambulation or prolonged standing in awkward postures for extended periods of time; and sometimes these operators live in the affected area themselves and thus maybe experiencing psycho-social stressors due to the disaster. Given the finite number of trained operators, the availability of different types of robots, and the increasing areas of the country needing assessment of damages using robots due to large-scale disasters, there is a critical need to examine naturalistic human/robotic interactions during recovery operations in affected regions. The study will create a fundamental, principled understanding of attributes of collaborations between human and robot teams that are resilient during disaster recovery operations to minimize costly errors and improve effectiveness of future disaster robotics response and recovery operations.

This RAPID award will provide critical and timely information on human/robotic interactions during robot-assisted Harvey recovery operations in the Texas Gulf Coast and surrounding locations impacted by flooding. The study will examine recovery operations that focus on inspections of critical infrastructure affected by the flooding and to assist with economic recovery across different types of structures (homes, factories, neighborhoods, etc.). The objectives of this study are to 1) document the relationships between the human (e.g., pilot) and the robot (e.g., unmanned aerial vehicle) to achieve specific recovery tasks (surveillance and inspections) in dynamically changing and unstable environments (e.g., flood-damaged infrastructure); and 2) determine the key contributors of poor human/robotic interactions to provide heuristics/guidelines for improved human/robotic interactions. Both qualitative and quantitative data collection and analyses techniques will be used: video observations to document the gamut of human/robot interactions during recovery operations, perceptions of workload/fatigue, trust in robots, usability, communication, and training gaps through surveys and interviews from the human teams, types and functions of robots used, operator physiological responses, and task productivity metrics. Findings obtained from this study will be rapidly disseminated to appropriate stakeholders (industry, government, public safety) for developing effective best practices in disaster recovery operations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This RAPID award examined human/robotic interactions (HRI) during recovery operations for three disasters?Hurricanes Harvey and Michael and the Kilauea Eruptions. The research team undertook a systems approach and examined the relationships between the human (e.g., pilot) and the robot (e.g., unmanned aerial vehicle) to achieve specific recovery tasks (surveillance and inspections) in dynamically changing and unstable environments (e.g., flood-damaged urban infrastructure). Although unfortunate, the extent of the damage from these events and the large number of robotic operations necessary for recovery provided a unique opportunity for this type of systems approach study methodology.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

 1) Researchers engaged as participant observers in 3 disasters (Hurricane Harvey, Kilauea Volcano, and Hurricane Michael) as well as two different simulations of disasters (Brazos Valley Search and Rescue). The team reported, via numerous publications, that:

- Over the days of a disaster operation, sUAS pilots do not fully recover from the day?s fatigue (return to baseline) over the course of the operation, indicating that they experience a culminating effect of fatigue as the operation progresses. However, there was high variability in how people responded to the disaster and every disaster was different.

-Pilot physiological responses and performance on the psychomotor vigilance task was used to operationally define fatigue

-For example, at Hurricane Harvey: After only a day at one deployment, pilots showed a level of fatigue impairments equivalent to those of alcohol intoxication at 0.05%, which is above the legal limit for manned aviation pilots (0.04%). This comparison was made based on the vigilance test responses and its comparison to normative data on Blood Alcohol Concentration levels.

-Many pilots arrive at the disaster site already fatigued and in a slept dept: This was obtained using the psychomotor vigilance task (lapses) data

- A predictable tempo of the operations of the disaster tends to impact the pilots? ability to mitigate fatigue and schedule sleep. This is typically dependent on those managing the disaster.

Specific HRI challenges identified during at Kilauea Volcano response were:

-Flying the sUAS using PPEs (respirators due to gas emissions) impeded communication and visual cues between human-human teams (pilot and safety officers)

-Night flights impacted landing performances - this was the first major use of UAVs for night operations

-Using new sensors (air quality sensors) introduced variability in perceived mission performance

-High levels of fatigue in operators

Tool/Evaluation Methods Outcomes:

 -The team developed methods for conducting field assessments of fatigue with pilots of small unmanned aerial systems (sUAS) HRI during disasters, which included intermittent vigilance testing in the base camp and continuous monitoring using wearable sensors in the field.

-The team also built and validated two apps (freely available to public and researchers) for (a) documenting individual pilot and team interactions during disaster responses, and (b) assessing operator vigilance decrements across 3, 5, and 10 minutes testing periods

The high human involvement in disaster robot operations requires that human performance during normal, novel, and emergency missions be as well understood as the performance of the robot itself. The objectives of this project were to assess fatigue states of pilots who flew sUAS missions while assisting with tactical response during three different natural disasters. We used performance and physiological measures to assess pilot fatigue. Our study, being the first of its kind to evaluate sUAS pilot states in real-world disaster response, raises a number of opportunities for future research. This includes translating proven successes in performance and physiological assessment methods used in other emergency response applications to sUAS applications in real-world disaster and incident response settings, to enable researchers know what works and does not work in this domain leading to development of better sensor technologies that can noninvasively, and in real-time collect sUAS operator data for performance prediction modeling.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

 The project has significant societal benefits and enables co-robot teams to offer more resilience during recovery phases of natural disasters such that economic and personal recovery from natural disasters, like Hurricane Harvey, is accelerated. The results obtained here can also be applied to rehabilitation robotics where stress and fatigue in patients can impede physical recovery. We are also currently translating what is learned to other emergency domains (e.g., emergency medical services, firefighting, etc.) and across different technology applications (exoskeletons, augmented reality) in other NSF funded projects on developing National Talent Ecosystem for emergency responders. Leveraging the research team?s strong connections and partnerships with various stakeholders, the team also organized lessons learned as educational/training workshops at several venues that target different stakeholders (industry, government agencies, academia, public safety) to translate the project?s findings. As such, findings obtained in this RAPID award has rapidly disseminated to appropriate stakeholders for developing effective best practices in disaster recovery operations. The workshop is now embedded into educational curricula by the research team who regularly offer courses in robotics and human factors.
